Lesson(Text Version).title: Spanish Alphabet Basics
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This Lesson goes over the basics of the Spanish alphabet and pronunciation.
Lesson(Text Version).description: In this lesson you learn about the basics of Spanish where you learn the alphabet as well as basic spanish phrases and sentences. The spanish alphabet contains 27 letters. It has one more letter than the English alphabet being Ñ. Each letter is pronounced very differently where each pronunciation is shown below. Spanish contains much of the same words as the English alphabet where I is yo, in is en, is is es, and am is soy. There are also some other common words such as he is el, she is ella, and spanish is espanol. When you combine these words, they combine just like the english alphabet so if you wanted to say “I am in spanish” you would just translate the words where you would say “Yo soy en espanol.” In Spanish there is also conjugation where you can’t say “El soy” in Spanish, which is very similar to English as people don’t say “he am”. However people do say “he is” where in spanish it translates the same where you would say “El es”. Almost everything in spanish translates the same from sentence to sentence at the beginning so when doing your translations make sure to do just translate each word as you go by.
trivia: Did you know that Spanish has conjugations just like English?
Did you know that CH, LL, and RR are considered digraphs, not letters, in Spanish?
Did you know that the Spanish alphabet originates from the Latin alphabet?

Lesson(Text Version).title: Spanish Speaking Countries Lesson
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson will go over the countries that speak spanish.
Lesson(Text Version).description: In this lesson you will learn about all the countries that speak Spanish in the world. In total there are 21 countries that have Spanish as their official language. In North America there are 10 countries that have Spanish as their official language. Within the continent 6 of them are in central america being Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Honduras, and Panama. 3 are in the Caribbean being Cuba, Dominican Republic, and Puerto Rico. The biggest one being Mexico resides right above the countries in central America. In South America there are 9 countries that have Spanish as their official language being Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay, and Argentina.
trivia: Did you know that 595 million people speak Spanish in the entire world?
Did you know that Spanish is the 4th most spoken language in the world?
Did you know that the United States has the second largest population of Spanish speakers in the world?

Lesson(Text Version).title: Basic Spanish Verb Conjugation Lesson
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson will go over conjugation of basic verbs.
Lesson(Text Version).lessonTitle: Lesson 3: Verb Conjugation - AR, ER, IR
Lesson(Text Version).description: In this lesson you will learn that there are conjugations in Spanish just like in english. In spanish there are 3 types of verbs that have different endings being AR, ER, and IR Verbs. When you use each one in a sentence, the ending changes depending on what the verb is subjected to you. For example if you wanted to say “I eat” in spanish, you would change the verb “Comer” in spanish to como, so it would be “Yo como.” In this lesson only present tense verbs will be discussed Some common verbs in spanish are ser (to be - permanent), estar (to be - temporary), tener (to have), hacer (to do/make), ir (to go), poder (to be able/can), saber (to know - facts), poner (to put), haber (to have - auxiliary/helping verb), querer (to want/love), decir (to say/tell), hablar (to speak), dar (to give), ver (to see), comer (to eat), tomar (to take/drink), vivir (to live), necesitar (to need), quedar (to stay/remain/be left), venir (to come). The only verbs that you need to know are hablar, comer, tomar, vivir, necesitar, and quedar. These verbs are the only verbs that don’t contain irregular verbs or verbs that don’t always directly follow the formula.
trivia: Did you know that Spanish has 16 distinct complete verb tenses?
Did you know that most Spanish verbs are conjugated irregularly?
Did you know that Spanish verbs are often used without an explicit subject?

Lesson(Text Version).title: Spanish Food and Related Verbs Lesson
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson will go over food and things related to it.
Lesson(Text Version).lessonTitle: Lesson 4: Food Vocabulary & Regular Verb Use – comer & beber
Lesson(Text Version).description: In this lesson we will be learning about food. In this lesson there are two verbs that correlate with eating. Those are comer and beber which both mean to eat and to drink and are regular verbs. There are a couple food vocab words that you will learn in this lesson which include leche (Milk), agua (water), hamburguesa (hamburger), manzana (apple). Just like how you conjugated with the verbs in the previous lesson you will do the exact same thing for here but just at the food at the end. For example “You eat hamburgers would be,” “Tu comes hamburguesas.” Some other food vocab words you can learn are pan (bread), arroz (rice), pollo (chicken), carne (meat), pescado (fish), huevo (egg), queso (cheese), plátano (banana), naranja (orange), fresa (strawberry), ensalada (salad), papas or patatas (potatoes), verduras (vegetables), tomate (tomato), cebolla (onion), ajo (garlic), frijoles (beans), sopa (soup), jugo or zumo (juice), refresco (soda), helado (ice cream), torta or pastel (cake), galleta (cookie).
trivia: Did you know that ceviche is so important to Peruvian culture that there's a holiday dedicated to it?
Did you know that tamales are traditionally made in large batches during Christmas and other Mexican celebrations?
Did you know that people in Argentina often eat locro, a hearty stew, on May 25th to honor the country’s revolution?

Lesson(Text Version).title: Spanish House Items and Related Verbs Lesson
Lesson(Text Version).shortDescription: This lesson will go over things around the house and verbs related to it.
Lesson(Text Version).lessonTitle: Lesson 5: Around the House – Vocabulary & Regular Verb Practice
Lesson(Text Version).description: In this lesson we will be learning about stuff around the house. There are three main verbs that you need to know being, llavar (wash), limpiar (clean), mirar (watch), Abrir (open). In the house there are many items inside but there are only a couple that you need to know for this lesson being puerta (door), platos (plates), peliculas (movies), cama (bed). The sentence process is once again similar to the previous lessons where you use the verb with I or he or they and use the conjugation with the object in mind. All of these verbs are also regular verbs. Some other common household items around the house are, mesa (table), silla (chair), cama (bed), sofá (sofa/couch), ventana (window), pared (wall), techo (ceiling/roof), piso (floor), baño (bathroom), cocina (kitchen), refrigerador (refrigerator), microondas (microwave), horno (oven), lavaplatos (dishwasher), fregadero (sink), espejo (mirror), ducha (shower), inodoro (toilet), toalla (towel), televisor (TV), lámpara (lamp), alfombra (carpet/rug), cortina (curtain), cuadro (picture/frame), ropa (clothes), armario (closet), cajón (drawer), escoba (broom), aspiradora (vacuum cleaner).
trivia: Did you know that Spaniards have a famous saying, 'mi casa es tu casa' which means 'my house is your house'? It reflects the warm and welcoming nature of Spanish-speaking cultures.
Did you know that the Spanish word 'casa' comes from the Latin 'căsa,' which originally meant 'hut' or 'cottage'?
Did you know that many Spanish homes feature exterior roller blinds called 'persianas' to keep rooms cool and provide privacy?
